SEARCH
Module com.example.teamalfred
Package com.example.teamalfred.database

Class User

java.lang.Object
com.example.teamalfred.database.User
public class User extends Object
User Class, Represents a user as object within the system. Passwords are stored in a hashed format using BCrypt. Also used within User Session as primary token

  • Constructor Details

    • User

      public User(String firstName, String lastName, String email, String mobile, String plainTextPassword, String userTypeString)
      Constructs a new User instance. Hashes the provided password. The ID field is not initialised by this constructor.
      Parameters:
      firstName - The first name of the user. Must not be null.
      lastName - The last name of the user. Must not be null.
      email - The email address of the user. Should be unique and not null.
      mobile - The mobile phone number of the user.
      plainTextPassword - The user's plaintext password (will be hashed).
      userTypeString - The type of user as a String (e.g., "student", "teacher").

    • User

      public User()
      Default constructor. Needed for frameworks or manual instantiation before setting fields via setters.

      The student's grade, or null.

      Returns:

    • getPassword

      public String getPassword()
      Gets the stored password hash. Note: This returns the HASH, not the original plaintext password.
      Returns:
      The BCrypt password hash string.

    • setId

      public void setId(int id)
      Sets the unique identifier for the user. Typically used when loading a user from a persistent store.
      Parameters:
      id - The user's ID.

      Sets the first name of the user.
      Parameters:
      firstName - The user's first name. Cannot be null or empty.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if firstName is null or empty.

      Parameters:

      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if email is null, empty, or invalid format.

      Throws:

    • setUserType

      public void setUserType(String userTypeString)
      Sets the user type from a String. Converts the string to UserRole enum.
      Parameters:
      userTypeString - The user type as a string (e.g., "student", "teacher").
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the string is null, empty, or not a valid user type.

      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if userType is null.

      Sets the class name associated with the user. Can be null.
      Parameters:

    • setPassword

      public void setPassword(String plainTextPassword)
      Hashes the provided plaintext password using BCrypt and stores the hash.
      Parameters:
      plainTextPassword - The plaintext password to hash and store.

    • setPersistedPassword

      public void setPersistedPassword(String hashedPassword)
      Sets the password field directly with a pre-hashed value. This is typically used only when loading user data from the database. Avoid calling this with plaintext passwords.
      Parameters:
      hashedPassword - The already hashed password string from the database.

    • checkPassword

      public boolean checkPassword(String plainTextPasswordToCheck)
      Checks if the provided plaintext password matches the stored hash.
      Parameters:
      plainTextPasswordToCheck - The plaintext password attempt (e.g., from a login form).
      Returns:
      true if the provided password matches the stored hash, false otherwise.

    • getFullName

      public String getFullName()
      Returns the user's full name, combining first and last name.
      Returns:
      The full name (e.g., "John Doe").

      Provides a string representation of the User object, primarily for logging or debugging. Excludes sensitive information like the password.

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object o)
      This method defines what it means for two distinct objects (in this case, two User objects) to be considered "logically equivalent". By default, Java's equals (inherited from the Object class) only returns true if two variables point to the exact same object in memory.

      We override equals() to provide our own definition based on the object's state (its fields). For a User, we decide two User objects are logically the same if they have the same id.

      Overrides:
      equals in class Object
      Parameters:
      o - A User object
      Returns:
      True if both User IDs are equal
